NPO "Kokoro-Nakuchu Bungaku-Henshu Kyoku" published a book "Dear Prime Minister, "Life-Saving Breakwater" from Tōjinbō" at their own expense.
I have published my 10th book, "Dear Prime Minister, 'Life's Breakwater' from Tōjinbō" under the title of self-publishing.
All the newspapers in the country have taken it up and many readers have sent in their feelings.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the content that was directly heard from the suicidal person about the social and structural environmental issues that are the cause of suicide in Japan, and to create a society that is good for living.

We have been patrolling the water's edge of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we have been supporting activities to find and protect those who are suicidal and help them restart their lives.

This book summarizes the issues heard from 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected, and I would like to appeal to the Prime Minister as a measure to prevent suicide, which is necessary for the country, the following 7 items.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) The reason for suicide is "human rights violation".
(3) The suicide is a victim of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The government is treating citizens who live outside of its jurisdiction as "others" and treating them with disdain.
(5) Mentally ill people, including those with depression, are drugged and treated as suicides.
(6) The "duty of care" for suicide risk areas is forgotten and commercialism is running wild.
(7) The teachings of new religious organizations that cannot be scientifically proven are lies, and acts of intimidation that threaten future retribution and demand offerings are extortion.
The religious organization that commits the crime of "fraud and extortion" should be publicly announced and excluded.

In that regard, I would like to introduce a part of the feedback we have received from readers of this book, such as, “I was moved by the strong mental fortitude of those who are involved in this activity,” or, “I was impressed by the former police officer’s attitude,” or, “I was moved by the fact that even though they are strangers, they support each other like family, and I feel like they are Bodhisattvas who are living.”
I saw a photo in a news article and tears came to my eyes as I thought, "What must she be thinking..."
I heard that suicide is increasing among people who are being pushed into a corner by the corona crisis.
It's really sad.
They are all like that.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can live happily with the lives we have been given.
I have a great deal of respect and gratitude for the staff who have poured their hearts into those who are suffering as if they were dying.
I think this activity is very hard on the body and mind, so I hope you will continue to support us in our efforts to raise awareness.
thank you.
kashiko
I hope that you, the readers, will become gatekeepers of life in your regions.

[Toba] Toba City announced on the 10th that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 12 people in 11 households as special subsidies for child-rearing and household living expenses in fiscal 2020.
The city said it is seeking a process to return the money to the person, while also apologizing and explaining the circumstances.
According to the city, the issue was discovered on January 27, 2021, when the guardians of children who had previously made payments came to confirm their past payments.
Confirming the 79 households and 182 individuals who were eligible for the payment in the same year, it was found that 12 households received the payment twice on July 20, 2020.
The city will provide 50,000 yen per child to households with non-resident income tax, targeting high school students and below.

The data was provided by a computer company that was contracted to extract the target children from the data, but the employee in charge mistakenly added the high school student to the data, resulting in double payment.
The staff of the childcare support room said, "We will take it seriously, check the data again, and make every effort to prevent recurrence and restore trust."

Introduction to pioneers of plant research, including data from Mount Hayachine ・ Hanamaki City Comprehensive Cultural Property Center Planning Exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Newspaper Company

An exhibition that pays tribute to the pioneers who laid the groundwork for the study of the flora of Mount Hayachine, a mountain known for its alpine plants, is being held at the Hanamaki City General Cultural Property Center in Ohasama until the 12th.

The book collects 124 valuable specimens and data that were collected by the predecessors, and introduces the footprints of the predecessors who were involved in the research of the plants on Mount Hayachine.

The study of the plants of Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Ivanovich Maximovich (1827~91) in the late Edo period, and continued with the collection of plants under his guidance by Sugawa Chonosuke (1842~1925), who was from Puru Town.
Maximo Witt, who was not allowed to walk freely in the country because he was a foreigner, collected data in Sukawa and conducted research for three years in Yokohama and Nagasaki.
Nukawa continued to support research after returning from Maximum Venture, and presented on the "Himezakura", "Sanguisorba obtusa", and "Aruncus dioicus" unique to Mount Hayachine.

After that, modern botanists such as Makino Tomitaro (1862~1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotusmecki", "Draba japonica", and "Arenaria katoana", which he discovered himself on Mt. Hakoban-yama in 1903, and which were collected by local researchers, and which he named.
From the display data, it is clear that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

In addition, the authors introduce Shimura Matsuzo (1874–1948), who was a principal of the Flower Village Elementary School and conducted botanical research while accompanying the investigation into the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamagawa Shichiro (1914–88), who was a curator at the Ohasama Museum of Natural History and was involved in

Yoshida Muneo, a researcher at the same center, said, "There are many studies piled up behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine. There are also connections between people. It is a great opportunity for researchers from the local area to the whole country to connect with each other."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is devoted to the faith and history of Mount Hayachine, and the second chapter to the geological features of the mountain as seen from the geological perspective, with a focus on the research of German geologists who laid the foundation of Japanese geology, such as Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927).

Discussions on the introduction of renewable energy and goals at the Amami Airport 2nd Decarbonization Promotion Council | Society and Economy | Nihon Shimbun Newspaper
The promotion council for decarbonization of Amami Airport held a meeting on the 9th in Kasaricho, Amami.

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Agreement Committee" (Chairman: Mr. Anou, Construction Bureau, Oshima Subprefecture Office; Members: 13), which was established to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Nakagami-cho, Amami City), held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members attended, including online.
We held a discussion on setting targets for decarbonization and introducing renewable energy with solar power as the main source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from each airport by 46% or more (compared to 13 years ago) by 2030, as part of its efforts to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050.
The council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to lead the way in planning for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting was also held in private, like the first.
According to Chairman Ando, who responded to the interview after the meeting, the meeting confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions from the same airport.
We have been working on a consensus that follows the guidelines of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, aiming at setting goals and introducing renewable energy.
According to the information distributed, the CO2 emissions from the facilities and vehicles of the airport in the base year of 2013 (excluding aircraft) were 1,476 tons.
Of these, 1321 tons, or about 90%, came from the lighting and air conditioning of seven airport terminal buildings, followed by 84 tons from aviation lighting and 71 tons from airport vehicles.
In the council, they discuss reducing emissions from these facilities and vehicles.
Chairman Ando said, "We are at the stage of passing the point. The direction of the committee members is consistent, and I want to make sure that the summary of the interim report is done properly."
In the future, the third meeting will hear opinions on the interim report, and the fourth meeting will hear opinions on the final report, and a promotion plan will be formulated.
"Sakasama Real Estate" Ellis Island Branch Opened to Attract People to the Island | Society and Economy | Nanhai Ribao
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" = 8th, Chinatown

The branch opening event of the real estate website service "Sakasama Fudou" that visualizes the thoughts of people who want to try renting empty houses or shops, was held on the 8th at the famous town famous community "entaku" in Chinatown, Yokohama.
The talk session explains the overview of the service provided by the operating company.

Representative Director of Okubo Shokai (Hokkaido, Rishiri District) who is in charge of the branch operation said, "If we do this on Okinoyama, we can attract people to the island and create a flow."

Kasama real estate is the opposite of normal real estate, where the person who wants to rent out their property releases their information to the landlord and contacts them, and if they agree, they contract with each other individually.
As a demonstration experiment to discover hidden vacant houses and establish relationships through vacant houses, On-Co Co., Ltd. (head office: Mie Prefecture) started the service in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch office to be opened in Kyushu.
It's the first time in the country.
About 20 people, including staff from On―Co and Tsukigino, employees of the town hall and the mayor's office, and local residents, participated in the event.

Representative Director Okubo explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "As the movement to bring in people from outside the island intensifies, I thought that if we could make use of empty houses and vacant shops, the town would grow even more," and went on to describe the circumstances surrounding the branch office opening.
"I want to help people who have something to sell or want to do something on the island, even if it's just one person or one thing, to advance their efforts," he said.
Representative of Ongakukan Mizutani Takashi said, "We need to discuss what we want to do with the empty houses, who we want to bring in, and what criteria we will use to make those decisions."
"The deeper the connection between people, the more information will be gathered," he said, calling for participation in the talks and cooperation in providing information.

The size, weight, and silver color make it look like an iPhone 6 to me.

I don't play games so the processing speed is the same as the Z4, just a little faster in my opinion.  I read a review that said the fingerprint recognition was slow, so it took a little time to recognize, but since it's faster than face recognition, I use this one.
